13.06.text: However tonight, to the best of my knowledge,

18.30.text: Insects play a unique role in culinary history.

22.17.text: In the west they don't usually factor into our cuisine,

25.16.text: but an estimated two billion people around the world

27.48.text: rely on bugs as a food source,

29.57.text: and some even consider them to be a delicacy.

32.67.text: In 2013 the UN released a report which recommended

36.36.text: consumption of insects as a healthier

38.35.text: and more sustainable alternative to other sources of food.

42.22.text: As food sustainability becomes increasingly important,

45.04.text: it will be necessary for us to re-think some

47.33.text: of our preconceived notions about eating bugs.

50.57.text: Tonight's speaker, Pat Crowley, is on the leading

55.09.text: He is the founder of Chapul,

56.91.text: the first company to mass produce

58.47.text: insect protein products in the United States.

61.49.text: Beginning with handmade cricket flour energy bars,

64.08.text: Mr. Crowley has grown Chapul through crowdfunding,

67.07.text: eventually taking the company on the hit TV show Shark Tank,

70.58.text: winning a major investment from Mark Cuban.

73.33.text: Mr. Crowley graduated from CMC in 2002,

76.31.text: with a degree in Spanish and psychology.

79.07.text: And in 2007 he received a master's degree in watershed

82.19.text: management from the University of Arizona.
